Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Better understanding of some statistical concepts not typically mentioned in an introductory statistics textbook. This is mostly because Joseph Chang is absolutely amazing and will pull in interesting topics and ideas (eg. Agresti Coull) that most intro classes would never go over. I also learned how to code in R and think in terms of a data scientist in a very accessible manner, which many CS or computational courses struggle with.

Basic stats concepts like probability, distributions, confidence intervals, regression, etc. Even though I'm not majoring in S&DS, I'm SURE what I learned here will be incredibly useful in analyzing data for research, whatever, in other areas.

Learning R was really great too. It's a spectacular data processing/analysis tool and I feel really prepared to use it for my own research/work now.
I learned more R than I ever thought I would learn.  The statistical theory was also a joy.
I learned how to use R and ways to apply statistics using R. This class, despite being the first of its kind, is a decent and rigorous introduction into statistics with computational applications.

I learned a TON. I had zero experience with statistics or R, but now I am in love. I now feel very comfortable coding in R, discussing the basics of statistics, and creating my own statistical experiments from scratch.
I learned fundamental concepts of statistics, and I learned how to code in a new language, R.
I learned the basics of statistics
Learned quite a lot about introductory statistics, but also a lot about R coding. Very interesting material and class overall.
Introductory R with statistics theory. Solid introductory course.
Basic statistics, how to use R.
I learned about R, hypothesis tests, power, constructing various intervals, and bootstrap.

I learned an incredible amount in statistics as well as R programming. The problems Professor Chang selected were especially insightful to the exciting and vast opportunities to apply statistics for analysis and truly how critical this skill is in the real world.
Good balance of R coding and statistical theory/conceptual frameworks.

I learned a lot in this course - from basic statistics topics like confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, regression, and probability to the basics of coding in R (tidyverse, bootstrap, simulations, etc).
basic stats knowledge
Stat knowledge and R

Learned basic programming skills in R along with introductory statistics. Especially later in the class, there is an emphasis on statistical theory whereas S&DS 110 is more geared towards learning the procedures.
hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, basic probability theory, understanding common misconceptions, basic linear modeling, computing, bootstrap
An introduction to statistics. Coding in R. A glimpse into current discussion in the field of statistics.
I learned how to use R, and the basics of statistics. This course got me interested in statistics, and I found the discipline really stimulating.
Basic statistic intro material, plus how to program with R studio!

How to program in R
How to understand and manipulate statistical problems
I learned a lot about statistics and applying it to real world situations. I also learned how to code in R.
With this course I was able to built some very good foundations for any future Statistics and Data Science courses I make take at Yale. Also, R is a very good skill to have non the less.

A pretty comprehensive overview of basic statistics, and a general sense of how these topics could be explored and applied in more advanced ways to different fields.
A basic familiarity with R.
This course taught me some of the most important fundamental concepts in statistics, and how to apply them to a variety of problems.

I learned a lot about probability, binomial and normal distributions, simulating scenarios in R, coding in R, z- and t-tests, the central limit theorem, and other fundamental statistics concepts and tests.
As my first introduction to stats, this class really helped engage me with the field of statistics and provided a good overview of some really important analytical techniques.

-understanding of goals of statistical inference
-techniques/measurements such as hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, p-values, etc.

I learned the basics of probability theory, statistical inference, programming in R, and got brief exposure to various specific topics in statistics and data science through this course. I came into the course with no prior knowledge or experience in any of these things, but now I feel comfortable with them.
Introduction to basic statistical tools, as well as coding with the R language and working with the R Studio package.
Proficiency in R and statistics
Not much. I still don't understand R.
R script, basic programming, and statistics skills
Basic survey of stats and basic skills of coding in R. Pretty cool idea for a course

I learned a lot about statistical analysis and how to program in R; we discussed regression, probability, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals, among other similar intro stats topics, and then applied all of these things to R.
It was a great introduction to the nuts and bolts of statistics, with some R experience thrown in. Amazing class!

We learned about basic statistics ("intro"), but the "intensive" part comes in with learning how to use R to both compute/run the statistics, but also to create simulations that model and prove those statistical concepts.
I really enjoyed this course and learned basic but important concepts in statistics. Additionally, I learned R.

I learned how to conduct a lot of useful statistical analysisfor example, how to create confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for different types of situations (e.g. small/large samples, and sample proportions, means, difference between prop/mean in different samples) and use Bayesian inference. In the process, I picked up the (widely used) programming language R and got to develop my problem-solving and coding skills. In addition, I really appreciated our emphasis on unpacking different mis-interpretations of statistical analysis and how that helped me learn to identify/be skeptical of misuse of data in everyday life, especially journalismwhether the subject be the relation of American poverty to college attainment or the size of Donald Trumps hand.
I gained a much better understanding of statistics and probability.
Good, practical introduction to statistics and R.

The course was a very good survey and integrated both coding and statistical analysis seamlessly. I do wish that we spent more time talking about analyzing data in the context of research or the real world, and not just in contrived problems from the textbook.

Ok class. Psets took a fair bit of time, and didn't help me master concepts as well as I'd like. The class was definitely more computation rather than trying to hammer in the concepts, which I had to figure out for myself. After talking to people in S&DS 230, this was the harder class.

I'm very glad this class became a thing this year because computation is so important these days. Intro Stats + R will be so useful in the future. I really do feel prepared to apply this knowledge in the future. Problem sets were really well written and had a great balance between reinforcing topics learned in class and new topics we had to brainstorm on our own. They also really helped reinforce R and I feel really prepared and proficient in R now.

Strengths: very accessible resources.
Weaknesses: more pen and paper examples would have been nice.

The Q&A forum was well organized, and the way this course was organized was also done right. This course is for those who don't have experience taking college-level statistics, but the difficulty of this class I believe should be scaled down a bit more to meet that level.

Lecture was very slow. I feel that we could have covered more material. Also, before the midterm, a longer set of practice problems would have been helpful. The strengths were that I learned a lot and the course was very approachable for a newcomer.

Some strengths were that the content was interesting, the professor was knowledgeable and fun, and the problem sets were challenging - in a good way.  A weakness was the lack of diversity among ULAs. I actually had a pretty bad experience during office hours once. I was the only female in a room of men, and when I asked the ULA for help with a problem, he kept asking questions like "You don't even understand the first part? Did you even go to class?" and it was incredibly humiliating. I felt ashamed for asking for help, which is not how anyone should feel during office hours.
Please move it from 9 am. It is so hard to stay awake
For some reason, the lectures were not that engaging, and I found it hard to get stuff out of the lectures. The material is very interesting though, and I really enjoyed our problem sets.
I loved the problem solving aspect of the course. Most everything you learn will be useful in some capacity.
Strengths of this course are the TAs, the professor, and the exams. The weaknesses of the course are lack of proper review sessions.

Professor Chang was engaging. The course struck a great balance between R and statistical ideas. The course wove together nicely and offered a lot of practical applications of the concepts we learned.

Weakness: Wish this class had a section but that's just wishful thinking.

Strengths: Engaging yet demanding psets.

The course was very well organized (lecture slides and r-files from class are put on Canvas). However, sometimes the structure of the lectures themselves is unorganized because one topic seems to flow into the rest. I think it would benefit future classes if Professor Chang made a point to differentiate how one topic differs from another (for example, how do confidence intervals for means differ from confidence intervals for proportions and how confidence intervals for means are the same).
kinda disorganized, but overall a fine, fun class.
Pretty good course. Wouldn't change much

The strengths of this course were the resources available and the emphasis on R. This class had many office hours available and some of the peer tutors were absolutely amazing. I visited Neil and Dan's office hours on Thursday Night every single week because their help got me through the course. What I wasn't able to learn in class, I was quickly able to learn at their office hours. In particular, Neil was very good at explaining concepts and super approachable. How he managed to help us all out so much throughout the entire semester still amazes me. The other strength mentioned above was the emphasis on R. After taking this class, I feel I am fairly proficient in R and can take future R based classes/conduct research with R. Honestly, I think this class teaches R better than it teaches stats. The stats sometimes felt rushed because there was such a strong emphasis on computing.

The main weaknesses of this class were the teaching quality, sheer amount of material and sometimes the difficulty. Professor Chang is one of the nicest and smartest professors I've ever had but he CANNOT teach. Literally everyone fell asleep in class and most people stopped going. He is also very awkward and uncomfortable with people asking questions which makes it harder to learn. I also think he is unintentionally unapproachable. He is very nice, but sometimes gets flustered and will just leave suddenly instead of answering your question after class. Another weakness mentioned above is the amount of material. This class covers many R concepts AND tries to cover basic statistics. This can be very difficult to do, and we did not get to many concepts that even high school stats classes teach (chi-squared). However, I will say we still managed considerable theoretical depth in the concepts we did cover. Lastly, the PSETS can have one or two problems that are just very hard. Every few weeks we got a PSET that had a problem that made me think "How could we possibly know this?" However, this is where Neil and Dan's incredibly helpful office hours came in . Whenever, I went to them, I usually got these problems solved.
Good class! Tests, which we all pen and paper, felt very very different from problem sets, which were all done in R.
Great, clear syllabus. Great feedback system, especially through piazza. Professor Chang really made sure we had enough resources and help.

I thought the lecture could have been more interactive, although I think that is just a byproduct of the discipline. I really like the content and pace of the course though, and believe that the problem sets were extremely fun to go through.

The organization was messy and the course was very much a "we'll figure it out as we go". No syllabus to help plan ahead which made it difficult sometimes considering how time consuming assingments could be

Strengths:
Love the computational aspect
Good amount of material covered

Weaknesses:
Could be organized better
Pace too fast in beginning

I thought the teaching within the classroom coding wise was very good, while explaining the concepts was not very good. The teacher used powerpoint to teach math, which I believe is not an effective way of teaching math. I think if the statistical concepts were taught on the chalk board it would have been much easier to follow along with the content.

One major flaw of the course that I would like to point out is the following. Home-works are supposed to help us revise the things we learnt in class. Not teach us new things that we had never come in contact with before. I believe that the PSet process would have flown a lot more smoothly if there was a more one to one correspondence with the things we did in class.

This course is very well organised. The problem sets really build off the lecture and allow for in depth exploration of the concepts covered. The problem sets also really allow for you to get comfortable with coding in R. You don't really realise it as you go along, but by the end, a lot of the R coding comes almost naturally because of how much you've done and learned. 
One thing that I sometimes felt a little lost on was the statistics theory. There were no formal discussion sections, and most of the office hours were spent looking at more R-based questions, so if you still had doubts after lecture and the book, or simply wanted to explore something a little further, it was difficult to find a place to do it in. Especially because although office hours were always very helpful when it came to R based questions, they lacked a little more strength in theory questions.
I think towards the beginning of the course, there could be a bit more focus on writing efficient, concise, elegant R code. Other than that, it is hard to imagine how the course could be improved.

The course was great because the lectures were very valuable and important to go to despite the lecture notes being posted (this was very helpful too). The problem sets were a great and very reasonable length, and drove home key concepts from lecture. Professor Chang also helped clarify questions about problem sets in lecture, and the entire course was geared to facilitate student learning. The material and the workload were very manageable. However the 5pm Friday problem set deadline was a bit weird and I would have loved for it to be midnight on Friday instead. Also, feedback on the problems sets was always super clear.

The course could provide more guidance for the more math and theory based concepts. On the problem sets, I feel like I had a solid grasp of the questions that dealt with applying the methods we learned to real problems, but I struggled a little bit with the more pure math or reasoning questions.
It's nice that the course teaches you how to use R. There might be some areas of content that other intro courses cover that this one does not though

It perhaps could move a bit more quickly once we get into the groove of things, but even that is a minor point. The class is supposed to be accessible to anyone, regardless of prior experience, and it succeeded in that regard. That's what is most important. The psets were also interesting and it was very useful to learn some R. Professor Chang was awesome as well.
Overall, a good introductory course.
I thought it was a very well done course.

The course is strong because it is a good beginner's introduction into both R and Statistics. I felt challenged (for sure) but I never felt wronged or like the coursework was wildly unfair. That being said, I think (to no fault of the class itself most likely) Yale students have a tendency to take the "beginners classes" even if they are not beginners, and that sometimes sped the class up to a point where it was difficult to keep up. I think in the future, the instructor will know what pace to go at more regularly and this problem will fix itself. All in all, strong beginner course into a fun but difficult subject.
I think the teaching could've been more comprehensive.
A very engaging course!

Strengths: problem sets were thoughtful and well designed by Chang. Tests were fair. 

Weakness: POWERPOINT! Its very hard to follow math and coding in class when none of the math or coding is done live but done beforehand and just clicked through in PowerPoint format

The structure of the course was good and everything progressed well from one topic to another. Using R for assignments and in class was helpful and I feel like I have a comfortable grasp on using R now. Lectures were well-organized and interesting, and the problem sets weren't too bad.

My only suggestion for course improvement would be that it's really, really hard to learn to code during lecture... Instead, I would make this part of the homework assignments and maybe do flipped classroom stuff during the lectures about R.

It felt a little disorganized as to us not covering some concepts provided in equivalent stats courses in other departments (i.e aqa, econometrics), but we did go deeper in proving statistical concepts using R.
As this is a new course, I hope it will become more organized.

I loved this course! One big strength is Professor Chang. Hes greatknowledgeable, fun, and well-organized (e.g. his hyper-linked Canvas homepage made me irrationally happy). This course also used Piazza well (shoutout also to David Brinda, who was really helpful in answering questions). The lectures were engaging and enjoyable; I looked forward to coming to this 9a class.

That said, the problem sets seemed like the backbone of this coursethey were where I internalized most of the material (which may be due in part to the 9a lectures)and I really liked them. They were all done in R (which led to me being caught off guard by the paper and pencil midterm) and collaboration was encouraged. They were usually composed of 4ish problems. Often, these would include a few more straightforward exercises, sometimes from our textbook, and then one or two that were trickier or that introduced new material. We did a couple of proofs near the end of the course, but problem sets usually focused on application and often simulation and visualization.

Oh, another strength: all the class materials are free! The main textbook (and extra for-fun textbooks) and the R software. As for weaknesses, while the lectures were definitely engaging and enjoyable, they could perhaps be better organized. In general, though, this was a great course, especially for its first time being taught.
I thought this was a very strong course - great professor, great problem sets, interesting material, etc. Lecture could be a little slow sometimes but always very relevant to the homework.
Yes! Learned a lot, even with a light workload.
Yes. If you're doing any sort of research, you'll have data and you need stats. R is just another huge plus. R will make your life easier.
Yes!!  Learn intro statistics and fun and practical way.
Yes, please take this course. Professor Chang is great and I'm sure he'll make this class better in the future!

Yes! Definitely take if you are interested in statistics or R. Don't let the "Intensive" part scare you, it just means that you will be using a lot of R in your homework (which is good!). I had zero experience with statistics or R before I took the course, and it was still very approachable and interesting. It is so good! Statistics is so fun!
Yes. The class was rewarding, and the professor was great.

This course at times felt very disorganized but that may be due to the fact that this year was the first year that this course was offered.  Prof. Chang is a really funny and smart person but can be a little longwinded and disorganized in his explanations.  The psets took several hours and were at times frustrating to someone who does not love coding.  If you love computer science and coding, take this class because there's a good amount of it.
Yes. As long as you focus and do the readings, you'll learn how to solve really fun problems.
Yes, great class for anyone thinking about doing statistics, but also great class in general because it's very applicable to many fields.

The psets are much harder than the inclass work, which is so boring you actively want to hit your head on the floor. Joe Chang doesn't teach very clearly, and the only reason I was able to know what was even going on is because I had taken stats prior.
Yep, solid class. If you want an easy class though, probably take another stats class It is "intensive" for a reason.
Yes! It gave me a wonderful basic understanding of statistics and how to conduct statistical tests.
Yes, I would recommend it to students who want to learn statistics and coding.
Yes! The teacher is great, and class is extremely useful.
A really great intro into SDS! Chang can appear a little soft spoken, but if you stick with him he will teach you a lot.

Yes. The statistics content of the course is largely the same as that of AP Statistics, so just be aware of that. Even though I took AP Statistics in high school, I really saw this course as an opportunity to expose myself to computer science and its more practical purposes.
Possibly. This class is somewhat disorganized, and grading takes forever. However, I did learn quite a bit and Prof Chang has an odd sort of charm to him.
Standard stats. Psets are interesting but lectures aren't. Can learn without going to class

I honestly wouldn't highly recommend this course. If you are willing to put the work in to go to office hours and get things done, it may be worth it and you do get a solid foundation in R, however, the class is unorganized, poorly taught, somewhat random (as far as concepts covered) and not too broad a foundation. This was Professor Chang's first year teaching the class, so I can not attest to how the class may improve in the future. I would say that I don't regret taking this class, but if I had the choice, I would not take it again.

If you want to learn stats with a bit of the computing, this is definitely a great route, much better than what I have heard about the other intro stats class. Don't be scared off by the "intensive" label, it wasn't more work than most classes, it should really just be called "intro stats with computing." And hey, "intensive" looks good to anyone else who looks at your transcript. Does not require any previous computing experience, this was my first exposure and everything was walked through really carefully. Don't hesitate to ask a TA if you need help, they explained to me how to make a "function" which revolutionized the way I could do things!
Great introduction to Statistics with great guidance and resources.

Yes - maybe not the best introductory class for people already set on statistics, but definitely a great class to take if you are unsure about whether or not you are interested in statistics. I thought this was a great way for me to get a feel for statistics, and pique my interest.
Yeah! It's a heavier workload than expected for an intro class, but its interesting!

Statistics unfortunately retains its reputation as a dry subject. This course didn't do too much to change this. 
You will learn R entirely in the service of your understanding of statistics theory something which the course makes explicit at the outset anyway.

Yes! If you are a student interested in data science or statistics I definitely recommend this course! This course is challenging but is not an excessive amount of work. The problem sets give a great opportunity to work on the new code that was learned in class and allows for an application of the statistics to real world scenarios.
Yes, I would. The course provides excellent foundations for anyone interested in following a further path in statistics and data science.

Absolutely. I'm speaking as someone who had never coded before, and knew next to nothing about statistics -- this course is really, really worth it. It gives you a really great overview of statistics, and introduces you to coding with R, but most of all, the way the professor structures it makes for a really great environment where even if you have little to no experience with any of the topics, you feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. Not to say that this isn't a challenging course, on the contrary, but it is very fair and approachable, even if you are completely new to its topics.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone seeking a deep understanding of introductory statistics.

Yes! I would definitely take this course. I had no experience in statistics before, and this course was a great introduction. The lectures are interesting and helpful, the problem sets are very manageable and relevant, and the exams are quite fair and like the problem sets. While I did have experience coding before, Professor Chang spends a good amount of time teaching students how to use R, especially in the beginning of the class (emphasis on "use," as you'll learn that more than the theory behind it, which makes sense as this is a stats course and not a CS course). Feedback from the TA's on problem sets was great as well. Definitely take this course if you're looking for a manageable but interesting and fairly challenging introduction to stats.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who's looking to get a solid introduction into the field of stats along with some practical programming skills with R.

Yes, it's a good intro course that not only teaches you how to do statistics, but also the guiding theories behind it. Probably also helps people considering the data science major decide whether it's for them
Yes! It was good, in-depth but not horrifyingly difficult introduction to statistics. I'm actually considering double-majoring in S&DS now because of it.
Yes, especially if you've never taken a statistics course and want to be exposed to some basic programming.
Yes, it was very useful.
Yes I would! Good course for beginners into coding and R and statistics. Honestly quite fun, although at times I was incredibly frustrated.
Yeah, if you need to take it, take it.
YES. Very interesting course! Very engaging.

This class is neither the best way to learn R nor the best way to learn statistics. The material was presented in a very complicated, confusing manner; despite having seen higher-level stats in other non-stats classes, I was very often confused by the material. The slides don't contain very helpful information, and the textbook was never really used except as a source for homework problems (the textbook material is presented badly too). 

If you want to learn R, take free online courses. If you want to learn stats, take a different course or read the appendix of the Wooldridge econometrics textbook for ECON 132. You'll learn more effectively and much more quickly.

Yes if you are interested in statistics. You might be able to coast through this class without much work especially if youve taken stats before, but dont expect to get anything substantial out of it unless youre willing to put in some extra work.
Yes, if you want a pretty good intro to R. I wouldn't take this if you've had no exposure to stats in the past, as even though it's "intro" everyone else seems to understand the stats already.

I would 100% recommend this course to another student. If you're debating whether or not to take this class or regular statistics, there is a right and wrong decision: the right decision is to take this class. While it's intensive, it's not intense--my friends who took regular statistics this semester spent the same amount of time on their problem sets as the students in intensive did, but it seemed like we had more accessible instructors (TF, undergrads, and of course Professor Chang), and our problem sets were MUCH more interesting. For example, we were given sample data from a company (real or fictional I'm not sure) and were able to analyze a gender gap in wages statistically. 

If you've never programmed before, this is an ~excellent~ way to learn that doesn't involve the pain and drama of CPSC112. If you have programmed before, then the parts with R will come really easily, and it's a great language to know. If you've learned R before, I doubt you'll learn much that's new, but you might perfect your skills and learn statistics at the same time.
Yes, if you haven't learned stats but want to learn R. But, do consider other options that do the same: econometrics, AQA, Psych-Stats, to see what best suits your needs.
Definitely. I love Prof Chang.

Yes! This is a great introduction to statistics (no statistical or programming experience necessary, though the latter can give you a little leg up in the first few weeks) with engaging lectures and problem sets, taught by a cool prof, and that has a manageable workload. Dont be scared off by intensive in the name, as long as youre willing to spend some time debugging and/or collaborating, youll be fine. Id recommend this even to people who dont need it for their major because a basic level of statistical insight is increasingly crucial to being an informed citizen in everyday life. Also, learning R is a great skill.
Yes, i loved this course and would recommend it to everyone.

Yes, this was a great course for someone who doesn't have any background in statistics to get up to speed quickly. I now have a good understanding of important statistical tests and concepts and learned how to implement them in R. I feel a lot more confident reading and interpreting papers and using these tools to understand my own results.
